chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom
sanskrit:
मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय ।
मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव ॥७॥
transliteration:
mattaḥ parataraṁ nānyat kiñcid asti dhanañjaya |
mayi sarvam idaṁ protaṁ sūtre maṇi-gaṇā iva ||7||
translation: There is nothing whatsoever higher than Me, O Arjuna. All this universe is strung on Me like clusters of gems on a thread.
commentary:
In this pivotal verse, Krishna declares His supreme position as the ultimate reality beyond which nothing exists. He establishes that He is the highest principle (Para Brahman) and that there is no truth, no reality, no existence superior to or independent of Him. This assertion forms the foundation for understanding the relationship between the manifest universe and its divine source.

The beautiful metaphor of gems strung on a thread illustrates how the entire cosmos, with all its diversity and multiplicity, is held together and supported by the one divine consciousness. Just as individual beads appear separate but are unified by the thread running through them, all beings and objects in creation appear distinct but are fundamentally connected through and sustained by Krishna's divine essence. The thread itself remains unseen while the gems are visible, similarly the Divine remains subtle and imperceptible while the material world is gross and perceivable.

This verse is crucial in establishing the non-dual yet personal nature of ultimate reality in the Gita's philosophy. It prepares the ground for the subsequent verses where Krishna will explain His various manifestations in nature. The verse emphasizes both transcendence (nothing higher than Me) and immanence (all is strung on Me), presenting a complete vision of divine omnipresence that neither reduces God to mere matter nor separates Him entirely from creation.
speaker: Krishna
